reasoning: The critique targets a supporting step in the essay’s case against WAM-convergence under antirealism: the ‘needle in an astronomical haystack’ framing that leans on a very broad space of possible minds/values. If that step were undermined, it would moderately weaken the antirealist pessimism about convergence, but it wouldn’t collapse the essay’s overall position (which also relies on motivation failures, realism-side worries, blockers/lock-in, power concentration, threats, etc.). The critique has some real force: humans are not sampled from all possible minds, and shared biological/neuropsychological priors plausibly increase expected overlap in reflective endpoints relative to a uniform-haystack picture. However, it only partially refutes the essay’s point because the essay already emphasizes divergence via extended reflection, self-modification, differing idealization procedures, and the need for very fine-grained agreement to hit a ‘mostly-great’ narrow target; clustered starting points may still be underpowered. The critique is mostly correct but somewhat overstated in implying the reference-class fix substantially raises convergence probabilities. It is clear, focused, and contains little dead weight.
title: Human-derived minds share clustered starting points that increase convergence odds
